page.title: 17Salwarpe Water Control
page.content: In 1963 approval was given to a scheme to build an entirely new{water {pollution control works}in the Salwarpe Valley to cater for the needs of the expanding town of Droitwich. Three possible sites were assessed, and the hamlet of{Ladywood,}(to the east of Droitwich),was chosen. The site is approx. 30 acres, and situated on the flood plain of the River Salwarpe. The main works have been designed to cope with an estimated flow of{3,850,000 gallons daily. Treatment of sewage began in{1970. Apart from the usual sedimentation tanks,bacteria and sludge-drying beds, an innovation from Holland was installed,{a Pasveer Ditch,}where raw sewage is subjected to prolonged and intensive aeration and completely purified.Surplus sludge can be dried, or stored without objectionable odour.
